author: BeauHD
title: Code.org Launches AI Teaching Assistant For Grades 6-10 In Stanford Partnership
text: [](//news.slashdot.org/index2.pl?fhfilter=education) [](//news.slashdot.org/index2.pl?fhfilter=ai) [Code.org Launches AI Teaching Assistant For Grades 6-10 In Stanford Partnership](//news.slashdot.org/story/24/04/11/2133245/codeorg-launches-ai-teaching-assistant-for-grades-6-10-in-stanford-partnership) [ (illinois.edu) ](https://www-edweek-org.proxy2.library.illinois.edu/technology/this-ai-tool-cut-one-teachers-grading-time-in-half-how-it-works/2024/04) [6](//news.slashdot.org/story/24/04/11/2133245/codeorg-launches-ai-teaching-assistant-for-grades-6-10-in-stanford-partnership#comments) [theodp](/~theodp)writes: From a [Wednesday press release](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/codeorg-launches-ai-teaching-assistant-in-partnership-with-stanford-302112628.html): "Code.org, in collaboration with The Piech Lab at Stanford University, launched today its [AI Teaching Assistant](https://code.org/ai/teaching-assistant), ushering in a new era of computer science instruction to support teachers in preparing students with the foundational skills necessary to work, live and thrive in an AI world. [...] Launching as a part of Code.org's leading [Computer Science Discoveries](https://code.org/educate/csd)(CSD) curriculum [for grades 6-10], the tool is designed to bolster teacher confidence in teaching computer science." EdWeek [reports](https://www-edweek-org.proxy2.library.illinois.edu/technology/this-ai-tool-cut-one-teachers-grading-time-in-half-how-it-works/2024/04)that in a limited pilot project involving twenty teachers nationwide, the AI computer science grading tool cut one middle school teacher's grading time in half. Code.org is now inviting an additional 300 teachers to give the tool a try. "Many teachers who lead computer science courses," EdWeek notes, "don't have a degree in the subject -- or even much training on how to teach it -- and might be the only educator in their school leading a computer science course." Stanford's [Piech Lab](https://piechlab.stanford.edu/)is headed by assistant professor of CS Chris Piech, who also runs the wildly-successful free [Code in Place](https://engineering.stanford.edu/magazine/stanfords-code-place-introductory-programming-course-offers-new-model-large-scale)MOOC (30,000+ learners and counting), which teaches fundamentals from Stanford's flagship introduction to Python course. Prior to coming up with the new AI teaching assistant, which automatically assesses Code.org students' JavaScript game code, Piech worked on a Stanford Research team that partnered with Code.org nearly a decade ago to create algorithms to [generate hints for K-12 students](https://code.org/research)trying to solve Code.org's Hour of Code block-based programming puzzles ( [2015 paper](https://stanford.edu/~cpiech/bio/papers/inferringProblemSolvingPolicies.pdf)[PDF]). And several years ago, Piech's lab again [teamed with Code.org on Play-to-Grade](https://codeorg.medium.com/stanford-ai-lab-builds-an-algorithm-to-help-teachers-grade-coding-homework-2ebf0cd5b603), which sought to "provide scalable automated grading on all types of coding assignments" by analyzing the game play of Code.org students' projects. Play-to-Grade, a [2022 paper](https://stanford.edu/~cpiech/bio/papers/playToGrade.pdf)(PDF) noted, was "supported in part by a Stanford Hoffman-Yee Human Centered AI grant" for [AI tutors to help prepare students for the 21st century workforce](https://news.stanford.edu/2020/08/06/hoffman-yee-research-grants-focus-ai/). That project also aimed to develop a ["Super Teaching Assistant](https://hai.stanford.edu/news/how-ai-based-super-teaching-assistant-could-revolutionize-learning)" for Piech's Code in Place MOOC. LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman, who was present for the [presentation of the 'AI Tutors' work](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CIaOwPwHNZ0)he and his wife funded, is a [Code.org Diamond Supporter](https://code.org/about/2020)($1+ million). In other AI grading news, Texas will [use computers to grade written answers](https://news.slashdot.org/story/24/04/09/212247/texas-will-use-computers-to-grade-written-answers-on-this-years-staar-tests)on this year's STAAR tests. The state will save more than $15 million by using technology similar to ChatGPT to give initial scores, reducing the number of human graders needed.
